qas.question: How are pharmacists regulated in most jurisdictions?
Who do most jurisdictions say can give scheduled drugs to the public?

answers.text: only pharmacists may supply scheduled pharmaceuticals to the public

qas.question: What body has stated that physicians can also dispense drugs under specific conditions?
What is the estimate of how many physicians give out drugs on their own?
What are pharmacists forbidden to do?

answers.text: form business partnerships with physicians or give them "kickback" payments
pharmacists cannot form business partnerships with physicians or give them "kickback" payments

qas.question: Who do no jurisdictions say can give scheduled drugs to the public?
What body has stated that physicians can't dispense drugs under specific conditions?

context: In most jurisdictions (such as the United States), pharmacists are regulated <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b7_0>separately from physicians<b7_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. These jurisdictions also usually specify that <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b5_0>only pharmacists<b5_0/><a1_1/><a1_0/> may supply scheduled pharmaceuticals to the public<a1_2/>, and that <a4_2>pharmacists cannot <a4_0><a4_1>form business partnerships with physicians<a4_1/> or give them "kickback" payments<a4_2/><a4_0/>. However, <a2_0><b6_0>the <a2_1><a2_2>American Medical Association<b6_0/><a2_1/> (AMA)<a2_2/><a2_0/> Code of Ethics provides that physicians may dispense drugs within their office practices as long as there is no patient exploitation and patients have the right to a written prescription that can be filled elsewhere. <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>7 to 10 percent<a3_1/><a3_0/> of American physicians<a3_2/> practices reportedly dispense drugs on their own.
